awd_titl_txt: CIF: Small: Adversarial Network Tomography: Inferring Network State from Manipulated End-to-End Measurements
awd_abstract_narration:
An accurate and timely view of a network's internal state (e.g., distributions of link delays/jitters/losses or various statistics of these distributions) is at the heart of many network management functions, such as traffic engineering, service placement, and fault detection/localization. Obtaining such a view has, however, become more challenging than ever in modern computer communication networks such as the Internet, hybrid optical/copper networks, future cellular networks, and distributed cloud networks, due to their increased complexity and heterogeneity. The traditional network monitoring approach that is based on pervasively deployed monitoring agents (e.g., SNMP) or pervasively supported network protocols (e.g., traceroute) faces severe limitations in such complex and heterogeneous environments. Network tomography, which aims at inferring the network internal state from end-to-end measurements taken from the peripheral of the network, provides a powerful alternative approach that can construct a view of the internal state without directly monitoring the internal links/nodes. Existing network tomography solutions, however, assume that all the internal nodes behave consistently in traffic forwarding, which makes them vulnerable in an adversarial setting, where certain nodes can manipulate the traffic traversing them to alter the end-to-end measurements. This project will investigate the vulnerability of existing network tomography solutions in an adversarial setting and develop guidelines for defense mechanisms. 

The primary objective of the project is to quantify the vulnerability of existing network tomography algorithms through rigorous vulnerability analysis, which involves actually developing the optimal attack strategy for each representative tomography algorithm and analyzing its impact in terms of the maximum performance degradation that an adversary can cause without being detected/localized. Concrete optimization problems will be formulated and solved for network tomography algorithms designed for different types of network states, including additive metrics that represent link delay/loss statistics, min metrics that represent available link capacities, and Boolean metrics that represent link congestion/failure states. Based on the vulnerability analysis, insights will be drawn on the reliability of tomography-based network monitoring in adversarial environments, and guidelines will be developed for future network tomography algorithms. The proposed research is grounded on latest advances on network tomography in the benign setting, including state estimation algorithms, measurement design algorithms, and theory about their limitations and performance. The research will be performed at the intersection of optimization and algorithm design, involving linear/non-linear optimization, combinatorial optimization, parameter estimation, and empirical validations. The project will provide training experience for students, some from underrepresented groups, through participation in the theoretical study, implementation of algorithms, and conduct of empirical validations based on real datasets from the Internet.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
An accurate and timely view of a network’s internal state (e.g., statistics of link delays/jitters/losses) is at the heart of many network management functions, such as traffic engineering, service placement, and fault detection/localization. Obtaining the network state through traditional approaches such as SNMP and traceroute requires support from internal nodes, which is not always available due to the complexity and heterogeneity of modern communication networks. Network tomography, which aims at inferring the network internal state from end-to-end measurements taken from the peripheral of the network, provides a powerful alternative approach that can reconstruct the internal state without directly monitoring the internal links/nodes. Existing network tomography solutions, however, assume that all the internal links/nodes behave consistently in traffic forwarding, which makes them vulnerable in an adversarial setting where certain nodes can manipulate the traffic traversing them to alter the end-to-end measurements. This project aims at investigating the limitations of existing network tomography solutions in an adversarial setting and providing guidelines for future designs.

The primary outcome of the project is a quantitative characterization of the limitation of existing network tomography algorithms in the face of intelligent DoS attacks launched by an in-network adversary. This is achieved through rigorously formulating and solving optimizations from the attacker’s perspective, to characterize the maximum performance degradation that the attacker can inflict on end-to-end communications without exposing the attacker-controlled links to network tomography. Efficient algorithms have been developed for solving these optimizations when the network state is defined as a vector of additive link metrics that can represent many canonical performance indicators such as delays, jitters, and loss statistics. Explicit conditions have been developed to characterize which subset of links, once controlled by the attacker, can lead to the maximum performance degradation without being detected by network tomography. Bi-level optimizations and corresponding algorithms have also been developed to design measurements for network tomography to maximally limit the impact of undetectable attacks under budget constraints.

The project advances the state of the art in network tomography beyond the traditional benign setting, by characterizing the vulnerability of existing algorithms to in-network adversaries and developing defenses in selected scenarios. Results obtained in the project call for awareness of a new attack surface in communication networks that can be exploited by in-network adversaries to mount attacks on end-to-end communications without being detected by hosts. This phenomenon provides another evidence for the need of regulations and auditing in public communication networks (e.g., Internet) to protect end users from in-network attacks and unfair treatments. Through a combination of theoretical analysis, optimization formulation, algorithm design, and empirical validations, the project has provided valuable training experiences for the involved students, including a student from underrepresented groups. Selected results have also been included in a book led by the PI on “Network Tomography: Identifiability, Measurement Design, and Network State Inference” published by Cambridge University Press.
